results.title: The century of cinema. Volume 2 (USA)
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Michael Henry Wilson, Florence Dauman and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
Scorsese’s enthusiasm for his country’s film history is infectious and it permeates this second volume of the Century of Cinema. Divided into three sections, “A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese through American cinema” doesn’t attempt to be objective or all inclusive. Instead Scorsese leads us through a fascinating tour of American cinema, conjuring interesting connections and unearthing lesser known gems. Includes interviews with Gregory Peck, Clint Eastwood, Billy Wilder, John Ford, King Vidor, Howard Hawks, Francis Coppola, Brian De Palma, Fritz Lang, Andre de Toth, Douglas Sirk, Nicholas Ray, Samuel Fuller, Orson Welles, Elia Kazan, Arthur Penn and John Cassavetes.

results.title: Hatari
results.creator_credit: Howard Hawks, Malabar Productions and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Director Howard Hawks reteams with John Wayne, who heads a group of highly skilled professional game hunters in Africa. They don’t use bullets, rather capturing the ferocious big game with rope and cameras for zoos and circus attractions, an exciting business that pits man against beast. “Hatari” means “danger” in Swahili and the fine cast of this spectacular adventure film also includes Hardy Kruger, Red Buttons and Elsa Martinelli and Gerard Blain.

results.title: White heat
results.creator_credit: Raoul Walsh, Louis F. Edelman and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The searing classic featuring the last great gangster performance by the legendary James Cagney. In 1931, Cagney stunned audiences with his portrayal of a no-good street punk in “Public Enemy” and helped define the screens’ image of underworld thugs. In “White Heat” he expands that image with a blistering performance as psychotic gangland kingpin Cody Jarrett. Devoted to his hard boiled Ma and possessed of an itchy trigger finger, Jarrett is a study of unequalled ferocity, a walking timebomb who robs, tortures and kills without conscience. When he is finally captured, Jarrett escapes a murder rap by doing time for a lesser crime. Still, “The Big House” cannot hold him and he escapes into one of the most famous finales of movie history. Driven by Raoul Walsh’s keen direction and Cagney’s vivid, hypnotic characterisation, “White Heat” won Life Magazine’s kudos as a wild and exciting picture of mayhem and madness.

results.title: Half a sixpence
results.creator_credit: George Sidney, Charles H. Schneer and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on the H.G. Wells novel ‘Kipps’, Tommy Steele stars as Arthur Kipp, a young draper’s assistant who inherits a fortune and enters Edwardian society. Arthur finds out that wealth doesn’t necessarily buy happiness. Apart from the lavish costumes, this production features some big numbers such as the title song and the wonderful “What a picture’. Also stars Julia Foster.

results.title: To live = Lifetimes
results.creator_credit: Zhang Yimou, Fu-Sheng Chiu, ERA International (HK) and Shanghai Film Studios
results.brief_description: To Live (or Lifetimes) is an extraordinary film which takes us through the major events in 20th century Chinese history. Gong Li and Ge You play a couple who struggle to survive in the midst of the tumultuous events that unfold in their lifetimes. With great power and subtlety Zhang Yimou places his characters in the fringes of the civil war, the great leap forward and the cultural revolution. Through their struggle to survive we experience the devastating effects of these historical events. Winner of the “Grand Jury Prize” and “Best Actor” in Cannes 1994, To Live is a moving tribute to all people who struggle to survive against the powerful arms of fate and history. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: The Baby of Macon
results.creator_credit: Peter Greenaway, Kees Kasander, Channel Four, La Sept and UGC Images
results.brief_description: Peter Greenaway’s film is visually sumptuous and confronting. Inspired by images of billboards featuring young children as icons, Greenaway’s film is set in the seventeenth century where child martyrs were similarly exploited. Rape, death, dismemberment occur when a miraculous child is the subject of a play that becomes too real. Stars Ralph Fiennes and Julia Ormond.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Greenaway, Kees Kasander, Channel Four, La Sept and UGC Images

results.title: I accuse = J'accuse
results.brief_description: Considered to be one of the most important anti-war films ever made, Abel Gance’s 1939 film is a remake of his original 1919 silent film. With the prospect of World War 2 imminent, gabel reconstructed his original to challenge the world. Jean Diaz is a research scientist who dedicates his life to ending war. When he discovers that his work is being exploited by the military, he summons up the ghosts of the war dead to make the world come to its senses.

results.title: A Story of women = Une Affaire de femmes
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Marin Karmitz and MK2 Productions
results.brief_description:
‘Une Affaire de Femmes’ has been hailed as one of Chabrol’s finest films. Based on the true story of Marie-Louise Giraud, a wartime mother and abortionist. Since the age of fourteen, Marie has been married to Paul, and has been a devoted and dedicated wife. When Paul returns from the war, he finds that life has changed. Marie-Louise has kept the home and family together and has plenty of money from her illegal business. She decides she no longer needs or wants Paul. The film exposes hypocrisy in its political and personal manifestations. Isabelle Huppert and Francois Cluzet star in this film which won an award for Huppert at the Venice Film festival and which was voted best film at the Melbourne International Film Festival in 1989.
Cast also includes: Marie Trintignant, Nils Tavernier

results.title: The Birthday party
results.creator_credit: William Friedkin, Max J Rosenberg, Milton Subotsky and Palomar Pictures
results.brief_description: Screenplay written by Harold Pinter. In a shabby seaside English boarding house, a man’s inability to cope with his fears and guilt comes to the surface. At first, in typical Pinter style, the conversation is trivial and banal but deepens and erupts from the commonplace and comic into terror. Stars Robert Shaw, Patrick Magee and Dandy Nichols.
